name: Spectacled Owl
description: Adult spectacled owls have dark coloration, light rims around yellow eyes, and a white or yellowish chest. Juveniles look like a negative of their parents—mostly white with a dark face.
spread_note: From southern Mexico to Argentina, some Caribbean islands
food_note: Mainly mice and large insects, also crabs, bats, opossums, frogs, and smaller birds
image_alt: Spectacled Owl, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Length 43–46 cm; wingspan 76–91 cm; weight 453–906 g
reproduction: Females lay 1–2 eggs, incubated for an average of 36 days.
attractions: The spectacled owl is a fast and agile flier. When hunting, it spots prey, swiftly snatches it, and returns to its perch. At other times, it picks animals from leaves and branches. The male emits a peculiar sound, like a hammer tapping a dry branch, while the female’s call is a piercing scream. Both parents take turns incubating eggs and caring for the young (usually only one survives).
breeding: One male lived at the zoo from 1966–1969, another from 1993–2008. Then a pair arrived, raising two young in 2014.
